choices: You Wake up in Reykjavic
You wake up in Ixtlan
1.content:
You are lying on a bench, trying to keep hold of your senses. You came to Mexico City
to work on your thesis about Yaqui Indian sorcery, where a student arranged for you to
meet a local man who was supposed to be very knowledgeable on the subject. The old
man met you at a bus stop and offered you a lemon drop, now you feel as if you’ve
been drugged. The man is standing above you now, chanting gibberish and staring
deeply into your eyes.

"I know what you're up to, don't try to pull any of that mind expanding Castaneda stuff on me
with your hypnotism and drugged candy!" You exclaim, gasping for breath.

"Life is like a journey to Ixtlan, you never know what's going to happen next." He replies calmly.

"Hey buddy, who you jivin' with that cosmic debris? Your Forrest Gump philosophy won't
work on me, and I've never even been to Iceland, although I did consider going there once
when I was younger.... I used to have a crush on Bjork..."

The old man continues to stare at you fixedly, and you feel as if you are falling backwards,
spinning into a long tunnel (like they used to have on that old "Time Tunnel" show on TV when
you were a kid, only not as cheesy.)
1.title: El Brujo

choices: Bjork looks at you, puzzled, and says "Do I know you?"
11.content:
"...There's definitely, definitely, definitely no logic...
Human, human, human, human..."

You open you eyes as the song fades to an end, a classic Bjork tune... You realize you
are now lying on your back in cool damp grass at a small outdoor venue you do not
recognize. The audience around you applauds in a polite Icelandic way, and you sit up
in time to see her take a bow and leave the stage.

You've always loved her! Your passion knows no bounds! You must see her! You
hurry towards the stage. As you get nearer you call to get her attention. "Bjork! Bjork!
It's me!"
11.title: Human Behaviour

choices: Mumble a hasty apology and walk away.
111.content:
"I realize you don't know me, but I've always loved you from afar." You tell her.

"And who are you?" she asks.

You stop and think for a moment. You can't tell her who you really are, an unemployed
assistant journeyman plumber staying on a couch at your sister's place, a roach infested tenement in a questionable neighborhood in Fort Worth. Suddenly, inpiration strikes:

"I'm a Poet!" you shout out, thinking to impress her.

"So, Mister Poet, I'm sure you must have a special poem just for me, extolling the
virtues of my beauty and telling of your unbounded desire. Please, may I hear it?" Bjork inquires cynically.

You start to sweat, you hadn't really thought this through. You know little of poetry, the only love poems you've heard recently have been those spoken by the robot-head on Lexx, but you know you’ll lose her if you don't say something quick.

You start to speak while still composing the words, trying to express feelings of beauty
and desire:
"Bjork, Bjork, my beautiful Bjork.
With eyes like a dove, and legs like a stork.
Please come for a ride in my pickup truck,
And then we can go back to my place and..."

SLAP! She strikes you across the face before you can finish the last word of your little
love sonnet.

"You pig! You are no poet! How dare you say I have the legs of a stork! And do you
think I would go riding with someone like you in a pickup truck, like some common
cowboy-girl?"
111.title: A Poet Who Don't Know It

choices: Think up something quick to impress her.
Tell her the truth.
1111.content:
You mumble a hasty apology and walk away, dejected, while members of her
entourage point at you and chuckle to each other, making rude comments about you in
Icelandic.

But before you get too far, Bjork jogs up behind you and taps you on the shoulder.

"I'm sorry I slapped you, that was very rude of me. But you weren't being truthful with me, were you? I know you are not a poet, so who are you?" she asks.
1111.title: Identity Crisis

choices: Bjork whispers, "me too."
Bjork whispers, "that's a shame, I'm with the resistance."
11111.content:
Ducking your head so she has to get closer, you whisper theatrically:
"I'm with the government."
Her eyes narrow, quickly you add:
"The real government."
"The real government?" She mimics in a beautiful, naive tone.
You glance around, and look inside your jacket as if looking for a secret recording device.
"The alien government."
11111.title: Think up something quick to impress her.

111112.author_name: Just here for the poke story
choices: "Please don't kill me!"
"Put your gun down or I'll use my alien powers!"
111112.content:
Her eyes narrow. You're sure you've been busted, no way would someone famous fall for something so stupid... well except maybe Paris Hilton.

Bjork reaches for something in the back of her outfit.

"That's a shame, I'm with the resistance."

"Wait what?" Is she playing a joke on you?.

She reveals a large silver gun. Either she intends to kill you, or she's very happy to see you.

You instinctively recoil and throw your arms up.

"Wait! Uh-"
111112.title: Bjork whispers, "that's a shame, I'...

choices: She agrees, but says this is not a date.
11112.content:
"Well Ma’am, I'm just a simple honest working man from Texas." you reply.

"Do you own a ranch?" she asks.

"No, I'm staying with family right now, but some day I do hope to have my own place."
you answer. (I know I said to "tell the truth" here, but glossing over the rough spots is OK.)

You notice that there is a small cafe on the corner in the direction you are walking.
Impulsively you ask her: "Would you like to have coffee with me?"
11112.title: Coffee Break?

choices: Wake up lying on a sidewalk with soda on your face.
Die of a heart attack.
111121.content:
You can't believe your luck! Bjork, the life-long woman of your dreams, has agreed to
have coffee with you! And unbelievably, she reaches out to take your hand, and you
walk together arm-in-arm, as if you were high-school sweethearts, towards the cafe!

Suddenly though, you begin to feel faint. There is a pain in your chest and your left arm feels numb. "I'm sorry, but I have to rest." you say, as you fall to the sidewalk.

"Oh my God! Someone call an ambulance!" she says, as everything around you fades to black.
111121.title: Just when things were starting to look good...

choices: Take another candy from the man.
Politely refuse, insist you must go home for dinner.
1111211.content:
You wake up lying on your back on the sidewalk with soda dripping from your face. You are no longer in Iceland, but are next to the bench back at the bus stop. The old man is standing above you, holding an empty Seven-Up can.

"So, have you learned anything on your journey?" he asks.

You reply, tentatively: "If I ever go looking for my heart's desire again, I won't look any further than my own backyard, because if it isn't there, I never really lost it to begin with?"

"No, that's not really it, but you were close, the answer is in Kansas." he continues. "I close my eyes only for a moment and the moment's gone. All my dreams pass before my eyes, in curiosity. Dust in the Wind. All we are is dust in the wind..."

"So, was any of that real? Was I really in Reykjavic with Bjork, or was it all a dream?" you ask.

"The answer is yes, to both." the old man replies. "Your body was here at the bus stop, but your dream was real. The concert in the park really happened or will happen, maybe in the past, maybe in the future. Time is an invention of society, there is more to reality than meets the eye."

"But what about Bjork, was she really there with me? If I walked past her on the street
tomorrow, would she recognize me?" you ask.

"She might not know your name, but she would most likely pause, perhaps ask if she knew you. Your souls have had the interaction you experienced in Reykjavic. Even if she did not
consciously remember you, her body would recognize yours, your lines of power would touch again upon meeting."

"So, would you like another lemon drop?" the old man asks.
1111211.title: There's no place like home, There's no pla

choices: You wake up sitting on a barstool.
11112111.content:
"Please, may I have another sir?" You ask jokingly. You take the candy from his hand
and swallow it without even chewing. Then you begin to anticipate the consequences of
your action, and your bravado begins to evaporate.

"This is crazy!" Why am I doing this?" you say to the old man.

"What would your father do in this situation?" the old man asks.

"You shut up and leave my father out of this!" you reply angrily.

"You seem to have issues about your father, would you care to talk about them?" the
old man questions.

"You're starting to sound like that lady psychiatrist on The Sopranos!" you complain.
"And no, I don't want to talk about it, and I'm sticking to my guns on that!" you
continue.

"Once you've made your decision stick to your guns, son!" is what your father used to
tell you. He managed to lose all of the family savings by "sticking to his guns" at the state-line casino poker tables though, and then had run off with a dancer, leaving you and your mom to fend for yourselves when you were only twelve.

"Perhaps some music, to soothe the savage beast?" the old man jokes. He clicks on a
small aging transistor radio, and starts fiddling with the dial. He manages to get a station somewhat tuned in. Although it is none too clear, you recognize the song "...somebody ought to tell her... that's not the Wichita way.."

"Hey, that's John Cowan!" you say to the old man. "I didn't think we had an Americana
format station around here, last time I heard that song played was on KPIG when I was
up in Santa Cruz!"

The old man just smiles at you and nods his head in time with the music. You start to
feel woozy, and find yourself sliding down to lie on your back on the bench.

The clouds are wheeling in a circle above you and your sight begins to dim as the song
fades: "... every night I dream of Wichita, that's the price I pay... show the world I ain't no quitter, that's the Wichita waaaaay....."
11112111.title: Wichita Way

choices: Stay at the bar and have another drink.
Leave quickly, try to find a place to bathe.
111121111.content:
You wake up sitting on a barstool, your head still fuzzy, a glass of warm beer in your
hand. The air smells heavily of cigar smoke and cow manure, and a man in the corner is
playing an old upright piano and singing an ancient ballad that sounds like something out
of an Old Western Melodrama:

"Thou wilt come no more, gentle Annie,
Like a flower thy spirit did depart;
Thou art gone, alas! like the many
That have bloomed in the summer of my heart."

Amazingly, a couple of teary eyed drunks sitting next to you at the bar are trying to sing along, and they even seem to know most of the words.

You look over at the guy on your right and ask, confused: "Hey, where the hell am I, and
why does this place smell like cow manure?"

"You're in the Golden Slipper Saloon, Mike, You had too much to drink? And you're
the one that smells like manure. No offense intended, but you sure could do with a bath
and a change of clothes."

"Hey, my name's not Mike, and I just took a bath last night!" you reply

"Heh-Heh, Mike Clanton, always the kidder!" the man replies.

You're starting to feel like you're in that old Star Trek episode where Kirk and the boys
were transported by aliens to an Old West town and forced to play the roles of the
outlaws that were gunned down at the OK Corral. The only difference is you seem to
be dressed for the part.
You realize that you have on a pair of well-worn boots with spurs, and a dusty gray Stetson on your head. Your partner is right, too: The levi's you are wearing look like they haven't been washed in a month, and they do smell of cow manure.
111121111.title: Days of Future Past

choices: Shoot it out with him.
Hit him with the nearest musical instrument.
1111211112.content:
You start for the door, hoping to get away unnoticed, when a man in a black suit with a tin star on his chest grabs you by the shoulder.

"Where you headin', Mike? Out to steal some more of our cattle?"

"I'm not a cattle thief, I was just leaving, going to take a bath." you reply.

"Gonna go wash that cattle rustlin' stink offa you is what I figure!" he says.

The men at the bar all step back, afraid, giving the two of you plenty of room.

"Go on, Mike! Go for your gun!" he demands.
1111211112.title: Quick Draw McGraw ?

choices: Steal the horse and escape.
11112111122.content:
You quickly grab a Spanish guitar from the hands of a nearby Mariachi and hit the Sheriff over the head with it.

"EL KABONG!" you shout, as you run for the door, with several of the Sheriff's men in pusuit.

Outside, you spot a white horse tied to the hitching post.
11112111122.title: Midnight Rider

choices: Freyja's House
Kingman Depot
111121111221.content:
Although it's been years since you rode, it all seems natural to you. You pull the reins from the post and quickly climb into the saddle and make your escape, heading East on the dusty road.

You hear the thunder of hooves in the distance, your pursuers. You think fast, guide the horse behind a stand of willows near the creek. Your ruse has worked, the riders speed past on the road as you hold your breath.

Once they are out of earshot, you double back, circle around the town, and head West.



"Go West, young man!" you mutter, and chuckle to yourself.

"Giddyap Silver!" The horse snorts, as if to laugh.

"Well hoss, waddya think? You up to a trip to California?"

You think back on when you were young... Leaving your home town, driving out west with all your meager possesions piled up in an old station wagon...

You'd just been dumped by a woman who meant the world to you. You remember playing your favorite Led Zeppelin tape while on the road, singing along:

"Made up my mind to make a new start,
Going To California with an aching in my heart.
Someone told me there's a girl out there, with love in her eyes and flowers in her hair."

...You never did find her though, maybe in this world? Or maybe it's all just a foolish dream, like in the song:

"Ride a white mare in the footsteps of dawn,
Tryin' to find a woman who's never, never, never been born."

After riding a couple of hours you spot a whitewashed building alongside the road up ahead. Once you get a little closer, you can read the wooden sign hanging from the front:
111121111221.title: Goin' to California

choices: Wake up on the bench, near the old man.
Wake up on the cot in the small room.
1111211112211.content:
You tether your horse in front of the building, it appears to be a bordello. There is a dim light showing through the window. You walk up and knock on the door.

A dark-haired woman opens the door, saying "Come i..." freezes mid-sentence, looking at you as if she is seeing a ghost.

You recognize her immediately. "Bjork?"

"No, no... my name's Freyja... Come in, I'm sorry. It's just you reminded me of someone I knew... Would you like a drink?"

"Whiskey, neat," You reply. She brings your drink.

"Sorry, all the girls are asleep, sunrise will be here soon. If you don't mind a more experienced woman, I could give you a tumble."

You consider the offer, but don't feel right about it. "No, and no offense to you, Maam. I'm just looking for a place to get some rest right now."

"Suit yourself. I've a spare room behind the kitchen. I let it out for a dollar a night."

You reach into your pocket, pull out a silver dollar and hand it to her. She shows you to the room. "Say, Freyja, you said I reminded you of someone. Mind if I ask who?"

"My husband, Lars.... He was the love of my life."

"What happened to him?"

"When I was young I dreamt of being in the Opera, a Diva. One day I was singing for Lars, and he just collapsed in front of me. The doctor said his heart gave out... He was so young..."

Freyja leaves you, walking towards the stairs in her sad reverie. You lie down on the cot in the small room, puzzling over the days events. But before too long exhaustion overcomes you, and soon you are fast asleep.
1111211112211.title: Searching for a Heart of Gold

choices: Man up and take a bath, it's got to smell better than you do.
Wuss out.  Hey, it's only cow poo!
11112111122112.content:
The burdens of your day have worn hard on your soul and you are so worn, not even dreams dare to disturb your slumber. When you wake up, you can tell it's late in the morning from the way the sun beams are forcing their way through the shuttered window.

         You sit up and grimace, pawing unhappily at the unwelcome light. After everything you've endured, you could use another few hours of sleep, maybe even a few days. Raising your arms above your head, you arch your back as far as you can and groan at the way it snaps and crackles. You sound like Rice Krispies on overdrive.

         There is a polite knock on the door and in a voice that sounds more gruff than you remembers yours being, you call out, "Come in."

         Freyja is standing there, a tray with a shot of whiskey upon it and a piece of bread.

         "All this and room service too," you smile and she smiles back, her eyes lighting up in a way that makes your head spin. You'd always had a special place for Bjork but even here, in the dusty west, she's enough to take your breath away.

         "I thought I'd let you know that if you wish, we have a bathhouse out back," she was too polite to mention the stench of my clothes too but I knew that if it was bothering me, it was bothering her too.

         I gestured to my filthy outfit and shrugged, "As you can tell, I definitely wish."

         She nodded her head and leaned forward to that I could take the whiskey and bread. The whiskey burned my throat and I nearly choked trying to keep from coughing. I didn't want to show my drinking inexperience to the beautiful madame before me. I grabbed the bread and quickly tore off a hunk to help dispel some of the liquor burn.

         Gnawing on the hunk of hard bread in my hand, I rose and followed behind her to the back door of the bordello. It was difficult not to be distracted by her trim form and the way that the clothes seemed to sculpt her perfect. I wondered if she knew how much I was drinking her in with my eyes.

         She showed me to the bathhouse which was little more than a small closet with a great big tin bucket in it. The water was a chocolaty brown color and my stomach flipped at the sight.

         "Is there clean water?" I asked, feeling for all the world like a city slicker but the water... it was almost chunky looking.

         She looked me up and down and I could practically see her disapproval growing in her eyes, "If the water is not up to your standards, you can pass on a bath here sir." I stared down at the tub and felt my dismay growing.

         This was not what I signed up for. I was ready to wake up and be with that old man again. No more lemon drops for me if it meant getting to smell like cow crap and bathe in chocolate water.
11112111122112.title: Wake up on the cot in the small room.

choices: Punch the courtesan
Run to the bathroom and clean yourself off!!!!
111121111221122.content:
You grab the dull bucket, and the slop of manure swills about "You can stay and watch if you want" you say. She raises her eyebrows and doesn't move. You sigh and begin to strip pulling off your filthy clothes.
"C'mon turn around, I wanna see your goods." she taunted.
You sigh and twirl for her, your dong swinging. You blush deeply as she exclaims "Wow sweetie, you're huge." Your glow of embarrassment changes to pride and you stand up proudly. Her fingers are crossed behind her back but you ignore and pick up the sloshing bucket. The wet cow pats swill about and the smell makes you blanche.
You then tip the horrible mixture over your head and she bursts out laughing "You fucking idiot!! This is the toilet, the bathroom is next door"
You look shocked and as the shite dribbles down your toned abs, you tremble with rage.
111121111221122.title: Wuss out.  Hey, it's only cow poo!

choices: Call out to the rider
1111211112212.content:
The depot is closed at this hour, but you notice someone sleeping under a blanket in the corner of the wooden porch. Tired from the ride, you decide to stop and do the same.

You tie the horse next to a nearby water trough and remove the saddle to use as a pillow. You pick a spot on the other end of the porch and lie down to get some rest. The night is warm so you are comfortable enough, even without a blanket...

You are awakened in the early dawn by the sound of a horse trotting towards the depot. You wipe the dew from your eyes, but still can't see who the rider is in the misty light. It's too late to make a break for it anyway.
1111211112212.title: Walk me out in the morning dew

choices: You're wounded, he's dead
You're both dead
11112111122121.content:
"Hello, good morning to you!" You call out to the rider, trying to be friendly.

"Hello yourself!" he responds.

You get a better look at the man, he looks for all the world just like this kid who used to be the class bully in your school. He dropped out later on, ended up in trouble with the law, and was given the choice of either enlisting in the Army or doing time. You later heard he was killed in 'Nam, just about a month before they ended it. You didn't feel sorry for him.

"You seen a Mexican whore around here? She run off with my whiskey money, and took my best goddam blanket too!" the man says, dismounting and walking up the steps.

"Nope, I didn't see no woman around here." You reply, but as you finish mouthing the words, you realize she must be the one who's sleeping under the blanket.

"There's the bitch!" he shouts, running after the woman, who is now trying to escape off the edge of the porch.

He throws her to the ground and kicks her savagely in the ribs, she groans in pain.

"Now you're gonna pay for runnin' out on me!" he roars.

"Leave that woman alone!" you cry out.

The man stops, rests his hand on a pistol at his hip: "If you want to live you'll stay out of my business. Just get on yer pony and ride on out, like a good cowboy."

This infuriates you, you're not gonna let him treat her like that. You never could stand to see a man hit a woman.

You reach for the gun at your side, he sees, draws his pistol too. You both fire at the same time.

BLAM! BLAM!
11112111122121.title: The good, the bad, and the ugly

choices: Leave. Alone. You've helped her, so your conscience is clear.
You help Lorana onto a horse, and head out to the nearest town.
111121111221211.content:
But wounded is always better than being dead.
However, now your shoulder is bleeding.

You decide to loot the sucker, and the woman helps.
You find a few pieces of gold, but not much else.
She then tears off a strip of his shirt to bandage your wound.

You take a good look at her.
Tan, with long, wavy black hair.
Too skinny, like she hasn't eaten well for weeks.
She is very bruised, and has a limp in her right leg.

She introduces herself, "Hola, me llamo Lorana."
You understand that her name is Lorana, however you can't speak Spanish.

You point to yourself. "I'm Mike."
She repeats your name, but looks at you warily.

You then...
111121111221211.title: You're wounded, he's dead

111121111221212.content:
The gunman falls to the ground on his back, a look of surprise on his face. You've hit him square in the chest, and can see the blood spreading across his dirty shirt as he dies.

You stagger, sit down on the edge of the wooden porch, realizing you've been hit too, in the throat. You put your hand up and feel the blood pulsing out between your fingers. Everything fades to black as you fall to the ground.

A few minutes later the woman rises from the ground, timidly walks over to check on the gunman. After she is sure he is dead, she picks up his pistol and takes his gunbelt, wraps it around her waist under her serape. She kicks him in the head, hard, and spits in his face.

She walks over to your body, goes through your pockets and retrieves a few gold coins. "Poor stupid Gringo..." she mutters, looking into your dead eyes. She closes them, gently, with her fingertips.

She saddles up your horse, ties the blanket behind her and rides off, deciding in light of recent events she'd better not stick around and take the train out after all.

"Hey Potro, will you carry me to California?" she asks the horse.

He snorts in aggreement, and they trot off down the road, with the early morning sun at their backs.
111121111221212.title: End of the Line

11112112.content:
You refuse the hallucinogenic candy: "No thanks, old man. I do believe I've seen enough. I must go home to dinner now, my wife is expecting me."

You return home to your small 3 bedroom 2 bath townhome, located in one of the several identical complexes in a well-maintained gated community on the outskirts of a
medium-sized modern, growing midwestern city.

You go to work 5 days a week, 8 am to 5 pm, have an hour for lunch, and two weeks
vacation a year.(Your last vacation you took your wife and your 2.3 children to Disney
World and Epcot.)

After the kids are grown you eventually retire at age 65, move to a senior community in Sun City Arizona, and die of a stroke when you are 68 years and 3 months old.

Kinda boring and predictable, huh?
(Well, unlike in real life, here you can always go back and try the other link.)
11112112.title: What a Long Strange Trip It's Been...

1111212.content:
You had to click this link to find out if it was true, didn't you! Well, see what you get?
This is it buddy, you're dead now! You died of a heart attack on the sidewalk in front of
that little cafe in Reykjavic.

Bjork was quite upset, but she got over it and went on to continue her career in singing, and occasionally acting in avant-garde movies like the ones you see on the independent film channels on cable .

As for you, your body was held in a nearby morgue and an article was published in the
Reykjavic paper looking for next-of-kin. Since no one there knew you, after a week
you were cremated and your ashes were buried in the local pauper's cemetery in an
unmarked grave along with those of local deceased vagrants.

(Hey it's a tough break, but if you don't like it you can always go back to the previous chapter and click on the other link.)
1111212.title: No fooling!

choices: Approach the smirking kid, demanding my wallet back...
Approach the smirking kid, asking for direction...
Using some money kept in your sock, you buy a bus ticket back to Mexico City...
12.content:
I blink. Perhaps I was having one of those acid flashbacks...hey, it was only once and the gods only know if that had been on that scrap of paper had been acid or just a high school prank...but it had to be something like that. Or perhaps it was some kind of new amoeba in the water. I know, I know...I should not have had the water and I had been doing such a good job of not drinking the water, but my soda was served with ice in it last night at the restaurant and I 'ate' the ice. Not the smartest thing, I know, but give me a break.

I slowly sat up, my head still spinning like I had too much tequila...like I was that poor donkey I saw at the tourist tequila factory trap...they would set bottles filled with booze in front of the poor animal and it would pick them up in its mouth and drink them as it swayed, sometimes staggering and falling over. I looked around. I was no longer in Mexico City, that much I knew. It was busy but not busy enough.

I blinked rapidly a few times, swiping the back of my hand across my eyes quickly as I scanned the area for some sort of sign, something that would tell me where I was even if it couldn't tell me how I got here.

EN ESTA COMMUNIDAD NO EXISTE LA PROPIEDAD PRIVADA PROHIBIDA LA COMPRA-VENTA DE TERRENOS COMMUNALES


Alright, well. I guess I won't be purchasing a summer home in the area. Sign tells me I can't own private property here but it fails to tell me exactly where 'here' is. I look some more. People are walking past me, ignoring me for the most part as I made myself slightly more comfortable on the bench I had awoken on. Most ignored me, but there were several kids staring at me like I had fallen from the sky. One looked a bit oddly familiar and he was smirking at me, but I was in no shape to go traipsing through my memories. I looked away.

Another sign...I squinted as it was a bit further away. Universidad de la Sierra Juárez. Ahhh. Okay. I know where I am now. I am in Oaxaca. Precisely, I am in Ixtlán de Juárez. I snorted. Ixtlán my arse. I hope this town gets a lot of money from moronic tourists who bought into that thieving Carlos Castenada.

Putting that scam artist who made good money appropriating the culture of native peoples aside, I had to decide how I was going to get back to Mexico City. I reached into my pocket, only to discover my wallet was gone and that kid was still smirking at me. The one who looked like a younger version of the local who gave me the lemon drop back in Mexico City
12.title: You wake up in Ixtlan

info.brief_description: Bjork, a Mexican Sorcerer, and maybe a trip to the Old West. Sound Interesting?
info.description: You find yourself on a bench at a bus stop under the spell of a sorcerer. The borders of your perception become fuzzy, there is more to reality here than meets the eye. What can you learn? Don't take it too seriously, though. (Kinda like a Carlos Castaneda tale with a Harlan Ellison twist.) Please rate, and add a chapter or two to keep the story going.
